tasks: Create a simple wireframe of a login form using the 8-point grid system, focusing on proper spacing and alignment (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system).
Conduct a self-assessment of your current user research skills by reviewing 2 existing case studies and identifying areas for improvement. Document your findings in a short report.
Redesign the navigation menu of this website using the 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design (Reference: https://www.nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics/).
Create a low-fidelity sketch of a product feature that addresses one of the pain points you identified in your user research report from Week 1. Focus on simplicity and usability.
Practice using the Zeigarnik Effect by creating a to-do list with 5 tasks and then removing 2 of them. Reflect on how this exercise makes you think about incomplete tasks in design.
Design a simple error message for a common user mistake, such as entering an invalid email address. Use the Law of Proximity to place the error message near the input field.
Create a high-fidelity wireframe of a product feature that addresses one of the pain points you identified in your user research report from Week 1. Focus on usability and accessibility.
Practice using the Aesthetic-Usability Effect by designing a simple visual hierarchy for a website. Use color, size, and position to guide the user's attention.
Redesign the navigation menu of this website again, but this time incorporating the Law of Proximity to reduce cognitive load.
Create a functional prototype of a product feature that addresses one of the pain points you identified in your user research report from Week 1. Focus on usability and accessibility.
Practice using the Law of Proximity by designing an error message for a complex task, such as uploading a large file. Use the Law of Proximity to reduce cognitive load.
Design a comprehensive design system for this website, incorporating all the principles you've learned throughout this 4-week program. Document your design decisions and rationale.

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the unique opportunity to craft intuitive and user-centered experiences that drive meaningful connections with your audience. By leveraging your skills in research, strategy, and collaboration, you can uncover innovative solutions that exceed user expectations and leave a lasting impact.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Applying Occam's Razor for Simplified Wireframes
topics.summary: Developing a clear understanding of Occam's Razor will help you create more efficient and effective wireframes, which is crucial for Explorer designers.
practice_points: Create 3 wireframes for a hypothetical product using Occam's Razor to guide your design decisions

topics.name: Conducting User Interviews with the Jobs-to-be-Done Framework
topics.summary: Mastering the Jobs-to-be-Done framework will enable you to conduct more effective user interviews and gain a deeper understanding of your users' needs.
practice_points: Conduct 2 user interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework and document findings

topics.name: Developing a Comprehensive Style Guide with Color, Typography, and Spacing Tokens
topics.summary: Creating a style guide will help you establish a consistent visual language for your designs, which is essential for Explorer designers looking to build their portfolio.
practice_points: Create a comprehensive style guide with color, typography, and spacing tokens
